item.title: The Handmade Book at Green Library, Bing Wing
item.description:
Stanford Libraries presents The Handmade Book, on view October 6, 2022, through February 5, 2023 in the Peterson Gallery and Munger Rotunda, Cecil H. Green Library, Bing Wing. 

The exhibition The Handmade Book is curated by Elaine Treharne and Benjamin Albritton, produced and designed by Deardra Fuzzell. 

NOTE: Exhibit cases in the Peterson Gallery and Munger Rotunda are illuminated from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Visitors are encouraged to call 650-723-0931 or visit the Library Hours page to confirm hours and access.

The exhibition is free and open to the public. Learn about the Libraries' entry requirements and available services.

item.title: Imagining Maritime Spaces Exhibition at David Rumsey Map Center
item.description: Imagining Maritime Spaces draws together maps of the world’s oceans and seas to explore how cartographers, navigators, and others have historically come to know and to represent these dynamic spaces. Charts, tools, and other visualizations illustrate elements of navigation by stars, winds, and waves, exploration of unknown waters and depths, and shifting coasts. This exhibit coincides with the Computational Archaeology & Seafaring Theory Workshop being sponsored by the Archaeology Center and collaborating centers and institutions both on and beyond campus. The exhibition was curated by Justin Leidwanger, Beth Minney and Nicole Constantine; it was coordinated and mounted by Kristina Larsen.  The exhibition opens at the same time as the Micronesian Seafaring System talk and can be viewed during the Center's open hours until Feb 10, 2023.

item.title: SSDS Bash Bootcamp
item.description:
Have you ever wanted to build a basic data science toolkit but can’t get started? No need for Python and R to hog all the credit, kickstart Winter Quarter with SSDS’s Bash Bootcamp!

This 4-hour data science project will boost your confidence through transferrable skills essential for the modern, data-driven job market.

Here you will learn the basics of the: 1) Bash programming language, 2) SQLite database engine, 3) Git for version control, and 4) free static GitHub Pages.

When: Friday, January 13 (all times PST). Online only, Zoom link provided upon registration. SUNet sign-in required.

  • Part 1 - 10:00-11:00 AM - Learn basic Bash code to navigate your computer’s file system and create directories and files using pwd, ls, cd, mkdir, and touch commands.
  • Part 2 - 11:00-12:00 PM - Launch SQLite3 and learn to wrangle data with SELECT, FROM, WHERE, GROUP BY, and ORDER BY.
  • 12:00-1:00 PM - Lunch
  • Part 3 - 1:00-2:00 PM - Build a Git repository to control version tracking with git clone, add, commit, push, and pull.
  • Part 4 - 2:00-3:00 PM - Use the GitHub repository you build in parts 1-3 and turn it into a simple static webpage with GitHub Pages.

Register here

Links to materials: BashGitHub, IntroSQLite, and GitHubPages.

Prerequisites: basic familiarity with computers. Sign up for free GitHub account.

 

Before the workshop - Mac users

Make sure you have the Xcode developer toolset installed. Open a Terminal and type:   xcode-select --install
When asked if you want to install the command line developer tools, click "yes/install"

 

Before the workshop - Windows users

Install GitBash here: https://git-scm.com/downloads. Download the file and double-click it to run the installer

item.title: Tabletop Tuesdays at Green Library, East Wing, SVA Seminar Room (Hohbach 126)
item.description:
Save the date for January's Tabletop Tuesdays (theme and featured games TBD). 

Tabletop Tuesdays is a new event series held on the third Tuesday of each month. At these events, we'll feature a selection of board games and collection items from across SUL's holdings around a specific theme. Drop in to learn about the month's featured game(s) and/or try some of the board games we have for open play at the Silicon Valley Archives.

item.title: CIDR Introduction to R
item.description:
This introductory workshop is geared towards those who would like to get started with R or need to brush up on their skills. You will learn how to use R, RStudio, how to create objects in R, how to work with different data types, how to read tabular data into R and how to subset tables.

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • None

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://cengel.github.io/R-intro

item.title: CIDR R Data Wrangling
item.description:
This workshop is for those who know the basics of R and would like to get started working with their research data. We will look into the tools that R provides to manipulate and explore tabular data, including reshaping, summarizing, and plotting. You will learn how to use the tidyverse package, in particular dplyr, tidyr, and ggplot.

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to R workshop (or equivalent knowledge).

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://cengel.github.io/R-data-wrangling

item.title: 2023-01-30 Intro To Arduino at Terman Engineering Library
item.description: Rapid prototyping and design requires some ready-made solutions, while some projects can be solved using simple computational technologies. Arduino microprocessors are one possible solution, being affordable, easy-to-learn, and relatively powerful with a little bit of knowledge. In this hands-on workshop, you will explore how to leverage these microprocessors for your research projects. No experience is required. If you have a computer with administrative privileges to install software, it is encouraged to bring it to the session.

item.title: CIDR R Data Visualization
item.description:
Data visualizations are essential to effectively communicate research. This workshop will review three base plots in R (histogram, boxplot, and scatterplot) before introducing you to the ggplot2 package.

Register Here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to R workshop (or similar experience).

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • Download R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • Download RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/data-visualization-ggplot2

item.title: CIDR Introduction to Python
item.description:
This workshop provides an introduction to the Python programming language: basic syntax, variable assignment, functions, data import, and how to understand error messages and find help. You will learn enough Python to perform common tasks and explore the rich environment of Python packages available. 

Register Here

Prerequisites:

  • Click here to set up your Google Colab environment before the workshop.

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/intro.html

item.title: CIDR Python Data Wrangling
item.description:
This workshop teaches basic data manipulation with Python using the Pandas library, and will cover topics such as loading data into and out of a Pandas DataFrame, performing basic data cleaning, preparation, and analysis, and visualizing relevant aspects of a dataset.

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python (or similar knowledge).

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Data_Manipulation_with_Python

item.title: Tabletop Tuesdays at Green Library, East Wing, SVA Seminar Room (Hohbach 126)
item.description:
Save the date for February's Tabletop Tuesdays (theme and featured games TBD). 

Tabletop Tuesdays is a new event series held on the third Tuesday of each month. At these events, we'll feature a selection of board games and collection items from across SUL's holdings around a specific theme. Drop in to learn about the month's featured game(s) and/or try some of the board games we have for open play at the Silicon Valley Archives.

item.title: CIDR Python Data Visualization
item.description:
Data visualizations are essential to effectively communicate research. This workshop will introduce you to three basic visualizations using the Python matplotlib and seaborn libraries: histogram, boxplot, and scatterplot. 

Register Here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar knowledge)

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/5_Data_visualization_essentials.html

item.title: CIDR R Text Analysis
item.description:
Are you interested in analyzing collections of novels or journal articles? Do you want to understand patterns across collections of tweets or other social media data? In this workshop, we'll learn how to import, clean, and analyze collections of text with R using several standard text mining libraries. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • The Introduction to R CIDR workshop or equivalent experience.

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://cengel.github.io/R-text-analysis/

item.title: CIDR R Machine Learning
item.description:
This workshop provides a beginner-friendly introduction to machine learning vocabulary and concepts, quantitative data preprocessing for machine learning, and the SuperLearner R package.

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to R workshop (or similar experience).

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/EastBayEv/Intro_ML_R

item.title: CIDR Python Text Analysis
item.description:
This workshop will introduce you to working with text data using the spaCy and textacy Python libraries. You will learn to effectively streamline text preprocessing, understand word tokenization, sentence segmentation, part-of-speech tagging, and named entity recognition using a single document (a short excerpt from H.G. Wells's A Short History of the World) and across a corpus of legal documents. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar experience)

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Text_Analysis_with_Python

item.title: Tabletop Tuesdays at Green Library, East Wing, SVA Seminar Room (Hohbach 126)
item.description:
Save the date for March's Tabletop Tuesdays (theme and featured games TBD). 

Tabletop Tuesdays is a new event series held on the third Tuesday of each month. At these events, we'll feature a selection of board games and collection items from across SUL's holdings around a specific theme. Drop in to learn about the month's featured game(s) and/or try some of the board games we have for open play at the Silicon Valley Archives.

item.title: CIDR Python Machine Learning
item.description:
This workshop provides a gentle introduction to machine learning vocabulary and concepts. You will learn the basics for classifying text and images using the scikit-learn, lime, and tensorflow Python libraries. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar experience).

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Intro_to_ML_with_Python
